subject: Relationships
title: Video Calls and Emotional Fatigue
description: A quick, practical guide to Video Calls and Emotional Fatigue.

hook.text: After the pandemic, couples in long-distance relationships reported 'Zoom fatigue' ruining their connection.

buildup.text: Video calls demand constant eye contact and exaggerated expressions. Your brain works overtime to feel present.

discovery.text: Stanford research found video calls cause more cognitive fatigue than in-person conversations of the same length.

twist.text: Phone calls ‚Äî without video ‚Äî may be better for emotional intimacy. Closing your eyes frees your imagination.

climax.text: Seeing someone's face on a screen isn't the same as being with them. Presence can't be digitized.

punchline.text: Video calls show faces but can't transmit presence.

quiz.question: What did Stanford find about video calls?
options: They're less tiring than in-person talks
They cause more cognitive fatigue than in-person conversations
